ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MALAY STUDENTS OFFERING MANDARIN AS THIRD LANGUAGE
(Survey)


    1. Encik Harun bin A Ghani asked the Minister for Education whether a survey has been conducted on the number of Malay students in secondary schools who show an interest in offering Mandarin as a third language and, if so, how many of them are keen to learn Mandarin and what is their family background.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Ker Sin Tze) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, a third language is an option offered only to top 10% pupils in the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE). My Ministry has not conducted a survey to find out how many top 10% Malay pupils may be interested to offer Chinese as a third language. The number is likely to be extremely small.

     Encik Harun bin A. Ghani (Hong Kah GRC): Sir, how many Malay students are there in the top 10% bracket?

     Dr Ker Sin Tze: According to last year's PSLE, there were only 163 Malay pupils who were in the top 10% bracket.

Column: 9

MALAY STUDENTS TAKING HIGHER MALAY AT 'A' LEVEL


    2. Encik Harun bin A Ghani asked the Minister for Education how many Malay students are taking Malay as first language at `A' level and what steps are being taken to encourage them to do so.

     Dr Ker Sin Tze (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the past three years, no school candidate has offered Malay as a first language (now known as Higher Malay) at 'A' level. Instead, about 200 Malay students each year take Malay language (formerly known as Malay as second language) at 'A' level. Pupils who passed Higher Malay at 'O' level are encouraged to continue studying Malay at a higher level beyond the minimum compulsory 'AO' level.

Column: 10



     Encik Harun bin A. Ghani: Sir, suppose some of them offer to take Malay as a first language at 'A' level, will the Ministry allow them to do so?

     Dr Ker Sin Tze: Yes, the Ministry will allow them to take as long as they meet the conditions. But judging from the statistics last year, the number is likely to be small. There was no school candidate in 1993. There were some private candidates, but the number was also very small. There were only three private candidates who took Higher Malay at 'A' level in 1993.

MEDISAVE
(Contribution by part-time self-employed people)


    3. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Health why is a person engaged in a second job of a self-employed nature on a part-time basis required to contribute to Medisave even though that person is already contributing to Medisave in respect of his regular full-time job.

     The Minister for Health (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, currently, a person who holds multiple employment is required to contribute to CPF from all sources of employment income. However, if his combined CPF contributions exceed the prescribed maximum, he may apply to have his CPF contributions capped at the maximum. His Medisave contributions will likewise be capped.

    The same principle applies to a person who is concurrently an employee and a self-employed person. He is required to contribute to Medisave based on all sources of income. Similarly, if his combined Medisave contributions exceed the prescribed maximum, he may apply to cap his Medisave contributions to the maximum amount.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, is the Minister aware that even if the Medisave account has reached its maximum, a person in this category is still required by the relevant Government

Column: 11

authorities, like the Registry of Vehicles for taxi licence renewal, etc. to continue to contribute to his Medisave account?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: If he has already reached the limit of his Medisave contribution, he can apply for it to be capped.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: But I understand that they are required to continue to contribute to their Medisave accounts. Any surplus would then be transferred from the Medisave accounts into their Ordinary accounts. What is the rationale of doing so?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The same rationale applies as it would to CPF contributions. In other words, if your monthly income exceeds $6,000 then you do not have to contribute CPF beyond $6,000. In the same way, the Medisave contributions will be capped. There are some minor variations depending on the age group you fall in. But the same principle applies. Perhaps if the Member has got specific details to raise, he can send them to me and I will give him a specific reply.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen: I will do so.

HDB PURCHASE FLATS
(Changes to allocation policy)


    4. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Acting Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will be making further changes to the allocation policy for purchase flats.

     The Acting Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board is currently reviewing the allocation policy and mechanism for HDB flats. It aims to reduce the uncertainties caused by the present balloting system, and give applicants more certainty as to when they can expect to be allocated their flats. HDB will ensure the scheme strikes a fair balance between new household applicants and upgraders.

    The details of the revised allocation system will be announced once they are finalised.

Column: 12



     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): Sir, when will this revised allocation system be implemented? Are we going to wait for a long time?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: It is not our intention to prolong the review. We will revise it as quickly as we can.

     Dr Vasoo: In that review, would the first-time applicants be given a higher weightage in the provision for public housing?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Currently, the first-time applicants are given higher priority. They are given their flats ahead of upgraders. We intend to retain this feature when we revise the system.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Thomson GRC): Sir, can I ask the Minister whether the review will also include a review of the income limit on people who are eligible for HDB flats?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB reviews the income ceiling for applicants of HDB flats regularly. We try to do this once in two years or when income increases rapidly. The review is due before the end of this year.

PARTY POLITICAL BROADCAST COMMITTEE
(Setting up)


    5. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Prime Minister whether he will set up a Party Political Broadcast Committee, which shall include the opposition, to review the rules concerning party political broadcasts at election time.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, party political broadcasts at election time are provided by SBC as a public service so that political parties need not incur large expenses to get TV airtime. The rules governing these broadcasts have been established by SBC over many years. They are simple, practical and fair. There is no need to set up a Committee with representatives from political parties to review the rules.

Column: 13



     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): I would like to ask the Minister about rules regarding some unforeseen change of rules by the PAP, for example, the introduction of the Elected President. We had a broadcast on that. Is that included in the rules?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Are we talking about General Elections or Presidential Elections?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Such things do happen at General Elections and the Opposition is often caught unaware on how the broadcast will be made.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I am surprised. The current system has been used in the General Elections of 1980, 1984, 1988, 1991. It is based on a formula which allows free airtime to major political parties to state their platforms in the four official languages on television and radio. Under the system, a political party fielding a minimum of six candidates qualifies for the minimum airtime of one period of 2 1/2 minutes in each official language broadcast. Beyond that, airtime is increased by half a minute for every four additional candidates fielded. There has been no change since 1980. So the rules are very clear and I do not anticipate that there will be change the next time round.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: These rules concern only the normal elections. But what happens at a General Election when something new suddenly comes up? Who makes the rules?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: If there are special conditions, like the new Presidential Election, then we will have to frame the rules as we go along. In the case of the Presidential Election which took place for the first time in our history we had to create new procedures for election campaigning to be done on television. We may have to make further adjustments next time round, but we will adjust as we go along. But the general principle is you get airtime in proportion to the number of candidates you field. As for the General Elections, there has been no change since 1980. So I am not quite clear what Mr Chiam is referring to.

Column: 14



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, there are two sets of rules. One set is for the general course of events, if nothing happens at a General Election. The other set is, if something crops up, there are no rules. I have given the example of the Elected President that was broadcast during election time. If you include the Opposition, then at least the Opposition would know what is happening rather than be caught by surprise.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I am not sure how you can stop the Opposition from being surprised. For a General Election, the rules are clear. So there should be no surprise for the next election. For the Presidential Election, since we had rules for the first time, there should be no surprise for the next election.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am not referring to the Presidential Election. I am saying that when a topic like the Presidential Election crops up during a General Election the matter is debated and broadcast. What are the rules in regard to that?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not appropriate for me to give answers to hypothetical questions.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: It has happened.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: What has happened?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Perhaps I am a more senior Member than the Minister. There was a party political broadcast or debate on the issue of the Elected President.

     An hon. Member: In 1988.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: 1988, yes.

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: In addition to party political broadcasts, if the parties involved agree, and SBC agrees, that there should be debate on specific issues, then such additional accommodation will be made on the basis of consensus.

Column: 15



     Mr Chiam See Tong: I do not know how you can say it is consensus when the party involved is not asked on the matter. How can there be consensus when the Opposition has been completely left out on the matter?

     BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, unless Mr Chiam can be more specific, I am not quite sure what question I am answering to.

     Mr Speaker: Neither do I.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I think the issue is very clear. The Minister has given an answer and he says there are rules for the general course of events, in other words, nothing crops up during a General Election. What happens when something crops up? What sort of rules do we adhere to?

     Mr Speaker: I think that is a hypothetical question and I would have to disallow that. Mr Chiam, would you like to proceed to your next question?

SINGAPOREAN PRISONERS IN THAILAND


    6. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs how many Singapore citizens are jailed in Thailand at the moment and whether the Government has taken steps to contact the Thai Government to alleviate the plight of these prisoners, in particular the removal of their leg chains.

     The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, 42 Singapore male citizens are in the prisons in Thailand, 20 of whom are serving life imprisonment for drug trafficking.

    In Thailand, the leg chain is used on prisoners considered most likely to attempt to escape. These are male prisoners below 60 years of age charged with committing serious offences which carry heavy punishments. Such prisoners have to wear the leg chain when they are detained in the remand prison while awaiting trial or when they are being transferred to courts or to other prisons.

Column: 16

The chain may be removed under certain conditions, for example, firstly, for good behaviour while under detention in the remand prison, as determined by the prison commander; secondly, when a prisoner has been transferred from the remand prison to a maximum security prison, after the Court has imposed sentence; thirdly, when a prisoner on death row has received the royal pardon and has his sentence commuted to life imprisonment or less.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when Singaporeans abroad are arrested for offences, our Missions will assist to ensure that our nationals are fairly treated. But those who commit offences abroad must also accept the consequences under the laws of the foreign countries, so long as they are dealt with in accordance with the due process of law. In this regard, each country has its own methods of punishment and procedures for dealing with prisoners. We cannot interfere in the operation of their legal process and cannot demand special treatment for our nationals.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, is the Minister aware that other prisoners in Thailand who have suffered the same punishment have their leg chains removed after the initial period, whereas Singaporean prisoners still have to suffer or undergo imprisonment with leg chains? Is the Minister aware of that?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the information which I gave just now of the circumstances and the categories of prisoners who, we understand, have to wear leg chains is supplied by our Mission in Bangkok. I have also ascertained from our Mission in Bangkok that the information and rules which I have described apply across the board and the Singaporean prisoners are not singled out for special treatment. If Mr Chiam has knowledge of any particular case where unfair treatment was accorded, and he will give me the specifics of the case, I assure him I will look into it.

    Having said that, let me also say that although we cannot insist that special treatment be accorded, from time to time appeals are made to the Ministry and to

Column: 17

our Mission to make representations on specific cases. For example, there was a case where a Singaporean prisoner's legs were weak and the Mission did assist in conveying the appeal. So this was acceded to, first, by a lighter leg chain, and later, the leg chain was removed. So the Mission and the Ministry will do their part whenever they can.

EMPLOYMENT OF PART-TIME FEMALE WORKERS
(Incentives)


    7. Mr Chia Shi Teck asked the Minister for Labour (a) whether more incentives will be introduced to attract females who cannot go into full-time employment to work part-time and (b) whether a lower employee Central Provident Fund contribution rate will be introduced for part-time workers so as to allow them a higher take-home pay whilst maintaining the 20% contribution from the employer.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, success in attracting the economically inactive females to join the part-time workforce depends on many factors. These include the benefits offered by the employers and the scheduling of part-time work for the convenience of housewives.

    My Ministry will ensure that our labour laws do not stifle the employment of part-time workers. In August 1990, the Ministry introduced a set of guidelines to help facilitate part-time employment. The Guidelines on Part-Time Employment were drawn up based on tripartite consultation and consensus. Under the Guidelines, statutory benefits are pro-rated based on the part-timer's contractual working hours in a year vis-a-vis that of a full-timer. Employers are also given the flexibility to encash certain benefits such as annual leave and public holiday entitlement for the part-time workers. The Ministry is conducting a review to formalise these guidelines into Employment Regulations so that the rights and obligations of the employers and part-timers are more clearly spelt out.

Column: 18



    With the Regulations in place to facilitate part-time employment, employers should come up with innovative schemes to meet the convenience of housewives so that more would come forward to work part-time. This would also help to alleviate our manpower shortage and reduce our reliance on foreign workers.

    On the Member's question of reducing the CPF contribution rate for part-time workers, my Ministry is not in favour of this. This is because CPF contribution is not the sole factor influencing the attractiveness of part-time employment. Reducing CPF contribution may not result in a larger number of people engaging in part-time work. On the other hand, any reduction in CPF contribution rates for part-time workers will affect some 47,000 part-time workers who are currently making full CPF contributions. Part-time workers also need to save for retirement and Medisave as much as full-time workers. The CPF scheme, as it is presently structured, helps them to do so. To lower CPF rate for part-time workers will create anomalies. A person working part-time but earning more may end up paying less CPF than another person working full-time but earning less.

    Finally, reducing the CPF contribution rate, even if it is the employee's contribution rate, may lead some employers to take into account the lower CPF contribution rate, hence, higher take-home pay, and therefore offering a lower basic wage to the part-time worker. The part-time worker may still not end up with a higher take-home pay.

     Mr Chia Shi Teck (Nominated Member): Sir, there are many categories of part-time workers. One category could be those who are engaged full-time and choose to work part-time over the weekends as cashiers or as service personnel in hotels. They already have CPF contribution in their full-time jobs. So for such work, does the Minister think there is a need for them to have the employee's CPF contribution, because they already have the CPF contribution?

Column: 19



     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in fact, my colleague, the Minister for Health, just explained a moment ago the principle behind CPF contribution. If you are working in several jobs, you will contribute according to the full CPF rate for all the jobs. But if the sums add up to more than the maximum required for CPF contribution, that is, $6,000 a month, then you can ask to have the contribution capped at this maximum of $6,000 a month. So this principle applies, whether it is full-time employment plus part-time employment, or a person working in many different jobs on part-time basis.

JOB-HOPPING
